content.description:
“On the plantation was a slave named Ben, who was highly prized...[for] being...the best and most faithful servant on the farm.... 
One day...the overseer thought [Ben] did not drive his oxen fast enough....Ben attempted to comply, by urging his [oxen] to their utmost speed. But [it did not work]. As soon as they met, the overseer struck Ben upon the head with the butt of his whip, felling him to the ground.... Before he could repeat the blow, Ben sprang from the ground, seized his [attacker and started] choking and beating him.... 
When [the overseer]...recovered...he [went inside and told the slave owner what had happened].... Ben...fled to the woods, where he remained about three weeks.
[When he was captured] Ben was soon bound in hemprope...[and] led to the place of torture, where he was whipped.... Poor Ben! his crime, according to the laws of Maryland, was punishable with death; a penalty far more merciful than the one he received....
Ben was a brave fellow, nor did this flogging lessen his bravery in the least. Nor is Ben the only brave slave at the South; there are many there who would rather be shot than whipped by any man.”  
Source: John Thompson, The Life of John Thompson, a Fugitive Slave; Containing His History of 25 Years in Bondage, and His Providential Escape. Written by Himself,  1856

choices.label: enslaved people bringing skills to the Americas, including blacksmithing and basket weaving

content.answer: resistance by enslaved people including slowing work and self-emancipating
